questions.text: C wave of JVP represents?

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A- Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

Explanation:

  • The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction, which is transmitted through the closed tricuspid valve.

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

a wave

  • Caused by atrial systole. (Option B ruled out)

  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.

  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave

  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve. (Option A)

x descent

  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave

  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria. (Option C ruled out)

  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent

  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a feed-forward mechanism?

choices.text: Increase in heart rate on standing from supine position
Increased cardiac output in response to anemia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D) Temperature Regulation

Feedforward

  • Description: Anticipates a change and initiates responses before the change fully occurs.
  • Examples:
    • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion (e.g., salivating when you see food).
    • Temperature regulation (e.g., shivering before body temperature drops significantly).
    • Anxiety leading to tachycardia (heart rate increase).

 

Vasoconstriction in response to cooling:
Feedforward Component: As discussed previously, the anticipation of a core temperature drop based on skin cooling provides a crucial feedforward element, allowing for a rapid, preemptive response.

 

Increase in heart rate on standing from a supine position:
Feedforward Component: The combined effect of increased heart rate, contractility, and vasoconstriction helps to restore blood pressure to near normal levels, maintaining adequate blood flow to the brain.

 

Increased cardiac output in response to anemia:
Feedforward Component: The increased cardiac output (achieved through increased heart rate, stroke volume, and reduced afterload) attempts to deliver more blood, and thus more oxygen, to the oxygen-deprived tissues. This is a compensatory mechanism to maintain oxygen delivery despite the reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

questions.text: Which organelle is not present in the designated region of the cardiac muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Lysosomes are responsible for intracellular digestion and waste removal. They contain enzymes that break down cellular waste materials and cellular components that are no longer functional.
  • The area marked is devoid of nuclei, and lysosomes are usually seen in perinuclear areas.

Incorrect Options: 


Option A. Mitochondria are abundant in cardiac muscle cells due to their high energy demands. They are responsible for generating ATP through oxidative phosphorylation, which is necessary for the contraction and relaxation of the cardiac muscle.
 

Option C. Golgi bodies are involved in processing and packaging proteins and lipids synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum. They modify and sort these molecules and direct them to their specific destinations within the cell or for secretion outside the cell.
 

Option D. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a complex network of membranes involved in protein synthesis, folding, and transport. It is responsible for the synthesis of proteins that are destined for secretion, as well as the synthesis of membrane lipids.

questions.text: Which reflex is responsible for tachycardia when the right atrium is distended?
questions.solution:
Correct option is D: Bainbridge reflex.

  • The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension. When the right atrium becomes stretched or distended due to an increased volume of blood, specialized stretch receptors in the atrial wall called atrial mechanoreceptors are activated. These mechanoreceptors send signals to the cardiovascular control centers in the brain, resulting in an increase in heart rate through the Bainbridge reflex. This reflex helps to regulate cardiac output by increasing heart rate to accommodate the increased venous return to the heart.

Incorrect options:

Option A: J reflex: The J reflex is a pulmonary reflex that is involved in regulating airway resistance and breathing. It is not directly related to tachycardia during right atrial distension.

Option B: Cushing reflex: The Cushing reflex refers to a physiological response that occurs in the brain in response to increased intracranial pressure. It leads to increased blood pressure and decreased heart rate, which is the opposite of tachycardia.

Option C: Bezold-Jarisch reflex: The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a reflex that can be triggered by stimulation of specialized sensory receptors in the heart, typically in response to excessive ventricular filling or ischemia. It leads to a decrease in heart rate, vasodilation, and hypotension.

questions.text: What is the cause of dicrotic notch?

choices.text: Passive filling of blood in ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Peripheral resistance:

  • The dicrotic notch is primarily caused by the closure of the aortic valve during ventricular diastole. This closure, in the presence of peripheral resistance, creates a momentary increase in pressure, leading to the notch in the arterial pressure waveform.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Passive filling of blood in ventricles: The dicrotic notch is not directly related to the passive filling of blood in the ventricles.

Option B - Rapid ejection phase: The dicrotic notch occurs during the diastolic phase, not the rapid ejection phase.

Option D - Isovolumic contraction: The isovolumic contraction is a phase of the cardiac cycle where ventricular pressure increases without changes in volume. It is not directly associated with the dicrotic notch.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Isovolumic relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) AV valves are closed.

Explanation:

  • Isovolumic relaxation is the phase of the cardiac cycle that occurs after ventricular systole when the ventricles relax but before they fill with blood.
  • During this phase:
    • Ventricles relax → Pressure falls.
    • Semilunar valves (aortic & pulmonary) close to prevent backflow.
    • AV valves remain closed until ventricular pressure drops below atrial pressure.
    • There is no volume change in the ventricles, only a pressure drop.

Cardiac Cycle Phases

Phase

AV Valves

Semilunar Valves

Event

Isovolumic Contraction

Closed

Closed

Ventricles contract but no ejection

Ventricular Ejection

Closed

Open

Blood ejected into aorta & pulmonary artery

Isovolumic Relaxation

Closed

Closed

Ventricles relax, no filling yet

Ventricular Filling

Open

Closed

Blood flows into ventricles

 

QT Interval (Option B): Incorrect because QT interval represents ventricular depolarization and repolarization, not just isovolumic relaxation.

'C' Wave of JVP (Option C): Incorrect because the 'C' wave occurs during ventricular systole due to bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium.

Semilunar Valves Open (Option D): Incorrect because semilunar valves are closed in isovolumic relaxation.

questions.text: What is the cause of dicrotic notch?

choices.text: Passive filling of blood in ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Closure of semilunar valves.

Explanation:

  • The dicrotic notch (incisura) is a small downward deflection seen in the arterial pressure waveform just after the systolic peak.
  • It occurs due to sudden closure of the aortic and pulmonary (semilunar) valves at the end of ventricular systole.
  • This closure causes a brief backflow of blood into the aorta and pulmonary artery, which is then halted, leading to a pressure rebound in the arteries.

Phases of the Arterial Pulse Wave

Phase

Event

Upstroke (Systolic Rise)

Ventricular ejection increases aortic pressure

Systolic Peak

Maximum arterial pressure

Dicrotic Notch

Semilunar valve closure and transient backflow

Diastolic Decay

Gradual pressure decrease as blood moves into periphery

 

Passive filling of blood in ventricles (Option A): Incorrect because ventricular filling occurs in diastole, unrelated to the dicrotic notch.

Rapid Ejection Phase (Option B): Incorrect because this phase occurs before the dicrotic notch, when blood is actively ejected.

Isovolumic Contraction (Option D): Incorrect because this occurs before semilunar valves open, while the dicrotic notch happens after they close.

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, point C denotes –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aortic valve opens

Explanation:

  • Point C specifically marks the opening of the aortic valve, allowing for the ejection of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta.

 

  • Point A: Represents the end-diastolic volume (EDV), just before the mitral valve closes and the ventricle begins to contract.
  • Point B: The point where the mitral valve closes and isovolumetric contraction begins, leading to an increase in pressure within the left ventricle without a change in volume. (Option A ruled out)
  • Point C: This is where the aortic valve opens and blood begins to be ejected from the left ventricle into the aorta during systole. This is typically the point marked after the isovolumetric contraction phase when pressure rises sufficiently to exceed the aortic pressure.
  • Point D: This is where the aortic valve closes, marking the end of the systolic ejection phase and the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation.(Option C ruled out)
  • Point E: The point where the mitral valve opens, allowing for the ventricular filling phase during diastole. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 65-year-old woman who arrives at the outpatient department with symptoms of breathlessness and fatigue? She has no previous medical history of reactive airway disease or heart disease, but she has undergone breast cancer treatment including breast conservation surgery and chemoradiation. On examination, engorged neck veins and jugular venous pressure (JVP) indicate a rapid x and y descent. The chest x-ray findings are as follows.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Constrictive pericarditis.

Explanation:

  • Constrictive pericarditis is a condition where the pericardium (the sac surrounding the heart) becomes thickened, fibrotic, and less flexible. This restricts the heart's ability to expand fully during diastole, leading to heart failure-like symptoms such as breathlessness and fatigue. It often occurs after chest irradiation or cardiac surgery, both of which the patient has experienced due to breast cancer treatment.
  • The symptoms of engorged neck veins and a rapid x and y descent in the JVP are typical findings in constrictive pericarditis. These signs reflect impaired diastolic filling and rapid early filling of the heart during diastole due to the rigid pericardium.
  • The chest X-ray findings would typically show pericardial calcification, which is a classic feature of constrictive pericarditis.

 

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): This condition involves accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, leading to pressure on the heart. While it can also cause symptoms like engorged neck veins, jugular venous distension, and breathlessness, the JVP typically shows a prominent "blunted" y descent (rather than the rapid x and y descent seen in constrictive pericarditis). Cardiac tamponade is usually associated with more acute symptoms, not the chronic course that would follow radiation treatment for breast cancer.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option C): This condition involves enlargement and weakening of the heart muscle, leading to heart failure. However, it is less likely to present with the characteristic rapid x and y descent in the JVP, which is more specific to constrictive pericarditis.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option D): This is a condition where the heart's walls become rigid, but it is typically due to amyloidosis, fibrosis, or other systemic diseases. It can present with heart failure and engorged neck veins, but the pattern of JVP is usually different, with a prominent x descent and a slow y descent, unlike constrictive pericarditis which shows a rapid x and y descent.

questions.text: In the cardiac muscle, the inhibition of Na +K +ATPase results in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Depolarization

Explanation:

  • The Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump plays a crucial role in maintaining the resting membrane potential of cardiac muscle cells by actively pumping 3 Na⁺ ions out of the cell and 2 K⁺ ions in.
  • This maintains a high concentration of Na⁺ outside the cell and a high concentration of K⁺ inside the cell, contributing to a negative resting membrane potential.
  • Inhibition of the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump leads to a reduction in the gradient of sodium and potassium across the membrane. As a result:
    • Na⁺ accumulates inside the cell, making the inside less negative (more positive).
    • This causes depolarization, as the normal negative resting membrane potential is reduced or lost.

 

PHASES

OPENING AND CLOSURE OF CHANNELS

Phase 0- Depolarization

Opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels

Phase 1- Initial rapid repolarization

Closure of Na+ channels

Opening of K+ channel

Phase 2- Plateau phase

Slower but prolonged opening of L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels

K+ channel also remains open.

Phase 3- Late rapid repolarization

Closure of the Ca2+ channels

Slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux

 

Phase 4- Baseline

Resting Membrane Potential About −80 to −90 millivolts.

 

Hyperpolarization and then depolarization (Option A): Inhibition of Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase generally causes depolarization, not hyperpolarization, because the loss of the Na⁺ and K⁺ gradient makes the cell less negative inside.

Hyperpolarization (option C): Hyperpolarization would result from an increase in the efflux of K⁺ or an increase in the influx of Cl⁻, but Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase inhibition causes depolarization.

Repolarization (Option D): Repolarization refers to the return of the membrane potential to its resting negative value, which doesn't occur with Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase inhibition. Instead, depolarization occurs.

questions.text: What does the image below represent in terms of murmurs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ejection systolic

Explanation:

  • An end-systolic murmur begins in mid-to-late systole and ends at the second heart sound (S2). These murmurs are typically associated with conditions such as mitral valve prolapse or late systolic mitral regurgitation.

Ejection systolic murmur:

An ejection systolic murmur is a heart murmur that occurs during ventricular systole, often due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed outflow tract or valve. The hallmark of this murmur is its crescendo-decrescendo pattern, indicating that it rises in intensity and then falls.

  • Timing:
    • Begins shortly after the first heart sound (S1) when the semilunar valves (aortic or pulmonary) open.
    • Peaks mid-systole and ends before the second heart sound (S2).
  • Causes:
    • Aortic Stenosis: Narrowing of the aortic valve leading to increased flow velocity.
    • Pulmona
    • Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Outflow obstruction during systole.
  • Sound Characteristics:
    • Best heard at the aortic area (right upper sternal border) or pulmonary area (left upper sternal border).
    • Crescendo-decrescendo pattern on auscultation.

 

End Diastolic (Option A): End-diastolic murmurs occur towards the end of diastole, just before the first heart sound (S1). These murmurs are often linked to conditions like mitral stenosis or tricuspid stenosis, which don't match the given pattern.

Pan Systolic (Holosystolic) (Option C): A pan-systolic murmur begins with S1 and extends through systole to S2. This is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, or ventricular septal defects, but does not fit a murmur ending late in systole.

Mid Diastolic (Option D): Mid-diastolic murmurs occur between S2 and S1, often caused by mitral stenosis, tricuspid stenosis, or increased blood flow through these valves.

questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, the "a" wave corresponds to:

choices.text: Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Right Atrial contraction

 

Explanation:

The "a" wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform corresponds to right atrial contraction.

  • Mechanism:
    • During the right atrial systole, blood is pushed into the right ventricle, causing a transient increase in right atrial pressure, which is reflected as the "a" wave in the JVP.
    • This occurs just before the first heart sound (S1) and the QRS complex on ECG.

 


Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform:

a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

 

Respiration Influence:

  • Venous pressure decreases during inspiration due to negative intrathoracic pressure.
  • Venous pressure rises during expiration.

 

 

 

Tricuspid valve bulging into the right atria (Option B) is incorrect because this corresponds to the "c" wave, which occurs when the tricuspid valve bulges into the atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

 

Right atrial relaxation (Option C) is incorrect because this occurs after the "a" wave and corresponds to the "x" descent in the JVP waveform.

 

Right atrial filling (Option D) is incorrect because this corresponds to the "v" wave, which represents venous return filling the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.

questions.text: In response to increased blood pressure, which of the following is released at the level SA node?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ACh

Explanation:

  • In response to increased blood pressure, acetylcholine (ACh) is released at the level of the SA node.
  • Increased blood pressure activates baroreceptors, which stimulate the parasympathetic nervous system to release acetylcholine.
  • This action decreases the heart rate by inhibiting the SA node, helping to lower the blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following curves represents gamma-globin chain production?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Orange curve

Explanation:

  • α₂γ₂ is the correct composition for fetal hemoglobin (HbF). It consists of two alpha (α) chains and two gamma (γ) chains.
  • By 6-8 weeks gestation, HbF (α2γ2) is the predominant hemoglobin; at 24 weeks gestation, it constitutes 90% of the total hemoglobin.
  • HbF declines modestly in the third trimester, such that the HbF comprises 70–80% of the total hemoglobin.
  • HbF production decreases rapidly postnatally and by 6-12 mo of age reaches adult levels of <2%.

Normal Human Hemoglobins:

 

Haemoglobin

Structural formula

Embryonic 

Hb Gower 1

ζ2ɛ2

Hb Gower 2

α2ɛ2

Hb Portland

ζ2ɛ2

Fetal 

Hb-F

α2γ2 (0.5-1%)

Adult

Hb-A

α2β2 (97%)

Hb-A₂

α2δ2 (1.5-3.2%)

Incorrect Options:

Green curve (Option A): This represents beta-globin chain production.

Black curve (Option B): This represents epsilon-globin chain production.

Blue curve (Option C): This represents delta-globin chain production.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg, and his pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased, resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Arterial wall compliance

Explanation:

  • Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure. It is inversely proportional to the compliance of the arteries.
  • When arterial compliance decreases (as in aging or atherosclerosis), arteries become stiffer and less able to expand.
  • This leads to a larger increase in systolic pressure, resulting in a higher pulse pressure. The arteries cannot absorb the pressure variation as effectively, causing the systolic pressure to rise more, and consequently, the pulse pressure increases.

Incorrect Options:

Myocardial contractility (Option A): While myocardial contractility affects stroke volume, it does not directly affect pulse pressure in the way arterial compliance does.

Stroke volume (Option B): Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume; however, a decrease in stroke volume would typically decrease pulse pressure, not increase it.

Cardiac output (Option D): Affects pulse pressure indirectly through its impact on stroke volume, but the primary factor in this case is decreased arterial compliance.

questions.text: If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen?

choices.text: Shift of the end-systolic volume and pressure curves to the right

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Shift of the end-systolic volume and pressure curves to the right

Explanation:

  • Reduced contractility shifts the end-systolic volume and pressure curves to the right on the pressure-volume loop, indicating that the heart is ejecting less blood per contraction.

Myocardial Contractility

  • Definition:
    • The intrinsic ability of the myocardium to contract and generate force, independent of preload (end-diastolic volume) and afterload (resistance against which the heart pumps).
    • Changes in contractility shift the Frank-Starling curve (relationship between stroke volume and end-diastolic volume).
  • Impact on Frank-Starling Curve:
    • Increased Contractility (Positive Inotropic Effects):
      • Shifts the curve upward and to the left.
      • Results in a greater stroke volume at any given preload.
    • Decreased Contractility (Negative Inotropic Effects):
      • Shifts the curve downward and to the right.

The Bowditch Effect

  • Alternative Names: Treppe phenomenon, staircase phenomenon, frequency-dependent activation
  • Definition:
    • An increase in heart rate enhances the force of contraction of myocardial cells with each heartbeat, independent of other influences.
  • Mechanism:
    • Related to calcium ion handling and mishandling in cardiac cells.
    • Involves proteins crucial for excitation-contraction coupling, such as sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium-ATPase (SERCA).

Aspect

Details

Positive Bowditch Effect

Seen in healthy hearts, related to SER Ca load alterations.

Negative Bowditch Effect

Pathological, due to diminished SERCA protein expression, hallmark of heart failure.

Clinical Significance

Shift from increasing heart rate to beta-blockers for improved cardiac function in heart failure.

Incorrect Options:

Decreased end-diastolic volume and pressure (Option A): Incorrect. Reduced contractility typically impairs the heart’s ability to fill properly during diastole, leading to an increase in end-diastolic volume and pressure as the heart struggles to adequately fill.

Increased stroke volume (Option C): Incorrect. Reduced contractility results in decreased stroke volume since the heart is less efficient at pumping blood, impairing its ability to eject blood effectively.

Enhanced response to sympathetic stimulation (Option D): Incorrect. A decrease in contractility usually indicates a weakened response to sympathetic stimulation, as the heart is unable to contract as forcefully as required.

questions.text: What is the cause of dicrotic notch?

choices.text: Passive filling of blood in ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Closure of semilunar valves.

Explanation:

  • The dicrotic notch (incisura) is a small downward deflection seen in the arterial pressure waveform just after the systolic peak.
  • It occurs due to sudden closure of the aortic and pulmonary (semilunar) valves at the end of ventricular systole.
  • This closure causes a brief backflow of blood into the aorta and pulmonary artery, which is then halted, leading to a pressure rebound in the arteries.

Phases of the Arterial Pulse Wave

Phase

Event

Upstroke (Systolic Rise)

Ventricular ejection increases aortic pressure

Systolic Peak

Maximum arterial pressure

Dicrotic Notch

Semilunar valve closure and transient backflow

Diastolic Decay

Gradual pressure decrease as blood moves into periphery

Passive filling of blood in ventricles (Option A): Incorrect because ventricular filling occurs in diastole, unrelated to the dicrotic notch.

Rapid Ejection Phase (Option B): Incorrect because this phase occurs before the dicrotic notch, when blood is actively ejected.

Isovolumic Contraction (Option D): Incorrect because this occurs before semilunar valves open, while the dicrotic notch happens after they close.

questions.text: A man presents with an irregularly irregular pulse and dyspnoea. What is the expected finding in the jugular venous pressure (JVP)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Absent a wave:

  • In the JVP waveform, the 'a' wave represents atrial contraction. An absent 'a' wave is typically seen in atrial fibrillation, where the atria do not contract effectively due to irregular impulses.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cannon a wave: Cannon 'a' waves are large, prominent waves in the JVP that occur when atrial contraction is against a closed tricuspid valve, often due to arrhythmias like complete heart block. This is not typically associated with an irregularly irregular pulse.

Option C - Prominent X descent: The X descent in the JVP represents atrial relaxation and descent of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole. Prominent X descent is generally seen in conditions like tricuspid regurgitation or right ventricular failure but not specifically in atrial fibrillation.

Option D - Prominent Y descent: The Y descent reflects the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle. Prominent Y descent can be seen in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis or right heart failure but is not a characteristic finding in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
Which of the following are properties of ventricular cardiac muscle?


	All or none law
	Length tension relationship
	Long refractory period
	Can be tetanized
questions.solution:
Correct statements

Statement 1: All or None Law
This is a fundamental property of ventricular cardiac muscle, which states that once a threshold is reached, the cardiac muscle fibers contract maximally. There is no partial contraction in response to a stimulus; the response is either full or none.

Statement 2: Length-Tension Relationship
Ventricular cardiac muscle follows the length-tension relationship, where the force of contraction is dependent on the initial length of the cardiac muscle fibers. This relationship is crucial for the heart's function, allowing it to pump efficiently by adjusting the force of contraction based on the volume of blood filling the heart (preload).

Statement 3: Long Refractory Period
Cardiac muscle cells have a long refractory period, which is significantly longer than that of skeletal muscle cells. This long refractory period is essential to prevent tetanization (sustained contraction) and to ensure proper rhythmic contractions of the heart.

Inorrect statements

Statement 4: Can be Tetanized
Unlike skeletal muscle, ventricular cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized due to its long refractory period. This characteristic is vital to maintaining the rhythmic and cyclical nature of heartbeats, preventing continuous contraction that would impede normal heart function.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the Emergency Room following a road traffic accident (RTA) with thoracic and abdominal injuries. The patient is found to be in hypovolemic shock. What is the most probable cause of the decreased cardiac output in this case?

choices.text: Decrease in contractility of the heart

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Decrease in preload

Explanation:

  • In hypovolemic shock, the body loses a significant amount of blood or fluids, leading to a decrease in circulating blood volume.
  • This reduction in blood volume results in a decreased preload — the amount of blood returning to the heart.

Types of shock:

Types of shock

Pathophysiology

Causes

Cardiac output

Cardiogenic

(Option B)

 

Inadequate pumping of the heart due to myocardial function.
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Heart failure
  • Cardiac arrhythmias

 

↓

Hypovolemic

Decreased amount of fluid in the vascular system
  • Acute hemorrhage
  • Burn
  • Metabolic: adrenal insufficiency, diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Severe diarrhea or vomiting.

 

↓

Distributive

Sudden increase in the vascular compartment capacity due to acute marked vasodilation
  • Neurogenic shock
  • Anaphylactic shock
  • Septic shock

 

↓

Obstructive

Obstruction to the ejection of blood from the ventricle
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Cardiac tumor
  • Tension pneumothorax

 

↓

Increase in preload (Option C): This is incorrect because in hypovolemic shock, preload is actually decreased due to fluid loss, not increased.

Increase in afterload (Option D): Although increased afterload can affect cardiac output, in the context of hypovolemic shock, the immediate cause of decreased cardiac output is the reduction in preload due to reduced blood volume.

questions.text: Windkessel effect is not shown by which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option C) Radial artery

Explanation:

Radial artery :

       It is a muscular artery (resistance vessel) that has a thick muscle coat and less elastic fibre in its wall. Due to less elastic fibres, recoiling property will not be seen.

  • It does not exhibit the same level of elasticity and compliance as large elastic arteries like the aorta

Windkessel Vessels:

  • The aorta and large arteries have more elastic elements in their wall (Options A, B & D ruled out). They have higher compliance
  • Windkessel effect: During systole, their wall stretches to accommodate the blood ejected by ventricles, and during diastole, their wall recoils back to the presystolic position .
  • The Windkessel or the recoiling effect pushes blood in forward direction during diastole.
  • Blood in blood vessels is pushed forward during systole by the force created by ventricular ejection and during diastole by the force created by arterial recoiling.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the zero phase of the action potential in the SA node?

choices.text: Sodium influx via voltage-gated sodium channels
Influx of both sodium and calcium

questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) Calcium influx only

Explanation:

  • The L-type Ca2+ channels are responsible for the slow depolarization (Phase 0) in nodal cells.

 

Incorrect Options:

Sodium influx via voltage-gated sodium channels (Option B): It occurs in atrial/ventricular myocytes and Purkinje fibres. Hence, the option is incorrect.

Potassium efflux (Option C): It is responsible for repolarization during phase 3. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Influx of both sodium and calcium (Option D): Sodium influx via "funny current" (If) contributes to the slow depolarization of phase 4. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Blood pressure changes in the radial artery were measured while performing a valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the reason for the initial rise in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increase in aortic pressure

Explanation:

Valsalva Maneuver

Phase I (onset of strain)
  • There is a transient increase in blood pressure that lasts for a few seconds.
  • This occurs due to increased intrathoracic pressure adding to the aortic pressure.

Phase II (phase of straining)
  • Venous return initially decreases, lowering cardiac output and blood pressure for 4 seconds.
  • Later, blood pressure returns to normal due to increased peripheral resistance from sympathetic vasoconstriction.
  • Heart rate steadily increases due to vagal withdrawal and sympathetic activation.

Phase III
  • This phase occurs following the release of strain characterized by a transient decrease in blood pressure lasting for a few seconds.
  • This is caused by the mechanical displacement of blood to the pulmonary vascular bed, which was under increased intrathoracic pressure.
  • There is little change in heart rate.

Phase IV
  • Occurs after further release of strain; blood pressure slowly increases, and heart rate decreases for about a minute.
  • This is due to an increase in venous return, stroke volume, and cardiac output.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the segment marked in red on the myocardial action potential curve?

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

Explanation:

  • The red segment marked on the myocardial action potential curve represents phase 2, the plateau phase of the cardiac action potential. The  plateau phase  is due to a slower but prolonged opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. The Ca2+ current is mostly due to opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels. 

 

Option (A ): Opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels together  doesnot occur in Cardiac action potential.  Opening of Na+ channels alone occurs in phase 0.

Option (C) : closure of Na+ and opening of K+ channels occur in phase 1 - initial rapid repolarisation.

Phases

Opening and Closure of Channels

Phase 0- Depolarization

Opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels

Phase 1- Initial rapid repolarization

Closure of Na+ channels

Opening of K+ channel  (option C)

Phase 2- Plateau phase (Option B)

Slower but prolonged opening of L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels

K+ channel also remains open.

Phase 3- Late rapid repolarization

Closure of the Ca2+ channels

Slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux

Phase 4- Baseline

Resting Membrane Potential About −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: The presence of a prominent 'v' wave of jugular venous pulse is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Tricuspid regurgitation

Explanation:

  • In a jugular venous examination, the presence of a prominent 'V' wave in the jugular venous pulse can be indicative of tricuspid regurgitation. Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart condition where the tricuspid valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow backward from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This regurgitant flow leads to an increased 'V' wave in the jugular venous pulse.

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

 

Wave

Details

Abnormalities

a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

Prominent a Wave: Tricuspid stenosis (Option C ruled out), right ventricular hypertrophy, pulmonary hypertension.

Absent a Wave: Atrial fibrillation (Option D ruled out)

Cannon a Wave: Atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve

 

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

-

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

Steep x Descent: Constrictive pericarditis, cardiac tamponade.

 

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

Prominent v Wave: Tricuspid regurgitation (Option A)

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

Steep y Descent: Rapid ventricular filling due to high atrial pressure.

 

Absent y Descent: Obstruction to ventricular filling (severe hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Isovolumic relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) AV valves are closed.

Explanation:

  • Isovolumic relaxation is the phase of the cardiac cycle that occurs after ventricular systole when the ventricles relax but before they fill with blood.
  • During this phase:
    • Ventricles relax → Pressure falls.
    • Semilunar valves (aortic & pulmonary) close to prevent backflow.
    • AV valves remain closed until ventricular pressure drops below atrial pressure.
    • There is no volume change in the ventricles, only a pressure drop.

Cardiac Cycle Phases

Phase

AV Valves

Semilunar Valves

Event

Isovolumic Contraction

Closed

Closed

Ventricles contract but no ejection

Ventricular Ejection

Closed

Open

Blood ejected into aorta & pulmonary artery

Isovolumic Relaxation

Closed

Closed

Ventricles relax, no filling yet

Ventricular Filling

Open

Closed

Blood flows into ventricles

 

[1]

QT Interval (Option B): Incorrect because QT interval represents ventricular depolarization and repolarization, not just isovolumic relaxation.

'C' Wave of JVP (Option C): Incorrect because the 'C' wave occurs during ventricular systole due to bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium.

Semilunar Valves Open (Option D): Incorrect because semilunar valves are closed in isovolumic relaxation.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Bain bridge reflex

Explanation:

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension. This reflex occurs when the right atrium is stretched, typically due to increased venous return, which stimulates stretch receptors. This stimulation increases heart rate to accommodate the increased blood volume and maintain circulation.

Bezold-Jarisch reflex (option A): The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a paradoxical reflex that causes bradycardia, not tachycardia, in response to myocardial ischemia or certain stimuli such as intravenous administration of certain drugs.

Cushing reflex (option C): The Cushing reflex is a physiological response to increased intracranial pressure, leading to hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration, not tachycardia due to right atrial distension.

Baroreceptor reflex (option D): The baroreceptor reflex helps regulate blood pressure by adjusting heart rate in response to changes in blood pressure, but it is not directly responsible for tachycardia caused by right atrial distension.

questions.text: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure increases in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cardiogenic shock

Explanation:

In cardiogenic shock, the heart's ability to pump blood effectively is impaired, which leads to an increase in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). This increase is due to the backward pressure from the left side of the heart (left atrium and left ventricle), causing fluid to accumulate in the lungs, which can lead to pulmonary edema.

Hypovolemic shock (option A): In hypovolemic shock, there is a decrease in blood volume, which leads to low cardiac output and low PCWP. The reduced circulating blood volume means less pressure in the pulmonary circulation.

Septic shock (option B): In septic shock, there is widespread vasodilation due to infection, which lowers systemic vascular resistance. This can lead to low or normal PCWP, not elevated, as the circulatory system compensates for the decrease in vascular tone.

Anaphylactic shock (option D): In anaphylactic shock, there is widespread vasodilation and leakage of fluid into tissues, which reduces the venous return and leads to low PCWP, rather than an increase.

questions.text: The first heart sound coincides with which phase of cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option C) Isovolumetric contraction

Explanation:

  • The first heart sound, also known as S1, is a low-pitched sound that occurs due to the closure of the atrioventricular valve during the beginning of isovolumetric contraction.

Phases of cardiac cycle-

Phase

Sub-Phase

Key Events

Systole

Isovolumetric Contraction (Option C)
  • Ventricles begin to contract
  • Ranges from closure of AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) till opening of semilunar valves.
  • First heart sound appears.
  • No blood volume change in ventricles

 

Ventricular Ejection
  • Has 2 phases- Rapid ejection phase and Reduced ejection phase.
  • Ventricular pressure exceeds aortic and pulmonary pressure
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves open
  • Blood ejected into aorta and pulmonary artery (Option B ruled out)
  • Ventricular volume decreases
  • Ends with the closure of the aortic valve.

Diastole

Isovolumetric Relaxation (Option D ruled out)
  • Ventricles relax
  • Ventricular pressure drops
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves close
  • No blood volume change in ventricles
  • Second heart sounds appears.
  • Ends with the opening of AV valves.

 

Rapid Filling
  • AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) open
  • Blood flows rapidly from atria to ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases rapidly
  • Third heart sound appears.

 

Diastasis
  • Blood flow from atria to ventricles slows
  • No change in the atrial and ventricular pressure.
  • Ventricular volume increases slowly

 

Atrial Systole
  • Atria contract
  • Additional blood pushed into ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases slightly
  • End-diastolic volume (EDV) reached
  • Fourth heart sound is produced.

 

Rapid atrial filling (Option A): It occurs during diastole, after the semilunar valves close (end of systole). This phase is unrelated to the first heart sound (S1) production, as the AV valves are open during this time.

questions.text: Which of the following possesses cardio-protective properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HDL:

HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) is considered cardio-protective due to its beneficial effects on cardiovascular health. Here's why:

  1. Reverse Cholesterol Transport: HDL helps remove excess cholesterol from the bloodstream and transport it back to the liver for disposal.
  2. Anti-Inflammatory and Antioxidant Effects: HDL exhibits anti-inflammatory properties, helping to reduce inflammation in the blood vessels. It also acts as an antioxidant, protecting against oxidative damage that can contribute to the development of cardiovascular diseases.
  3. Vasodilation and Endothelial Function: HDL promotes the production of nitric oxide, a molecule that helps relax and dilate blood vessels, improving blood flow and maintaining healthy endothelial function.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein):

  • LDL is often referred to as "bad" cholesterol because elevated levels of LDL can contribute to the development of atherosclerosis and increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases. LDL carries cholesterol from the liver to the tissues, and when LDL levels are high, it can lead to the deposition of cholesterol in the arterial walls.

Option B - VLDL (Very-Low-Density Lipoprotein):

  • VLDL is another lipoprotein involved in the transport of triglycerides and cholesterol in the bloodstream. Elevated levels of VLDL are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, as VLDL can be converted into LDL particles.

Option D - IDL (Intermediate-Density Lipoprotein):

  • IDL is a transitional lipoprotein that is formed during the metabolism of VLDL. It eventually gets converted into LDL. Elevated levels of IDL can be associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: Which of the options below can be used to elucidate the mechanism by which ANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) exerts its effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - cGMP:

  • ANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) is a hormone that is produced by the heart and plays a role in regulating blood pressure and fluid balance in the body. ANP acts on the kidneys to increase the excretion of sodium and water, which helps to reduce blood volume and lower blood pressure.
  • The mechanism of action of ANP involves the activation of cGMP (cyclic guanosine monophosphate). ANP binds to its receptor on the surface of target cells, which activates the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. Guanylyl cyclase then converts GTP (guanosine triphosphate) to cGMP, which acts as a second messenger to mediate the effects of ANP.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - cAMP: Hormones acting through this pathway are ACTH, TSH, FSH, LH, catecholamines, somatostatin, glucagon, and secretin.

Option C - IP3-DAG: Hormones acting through this pathway are TRH, GnRH, GHRH, Oxytocin, and ADH (V1 receptor).

Option D - JAK/STAT: Hormones acting through this pathway are growth hormone and prolactin hormone.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about isovolumetric relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - AV Valves are closed:

  • During isovolumetric relaxation, the ventricles are relaxing, and the AV valves are closed. Both the tricuspid and mitral valves prevent blood from flowing back into the atria.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Semilunar valves open: Isovolumetric relaxation is a phase where both the AV valves (tricuspid and mitral valves) and the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary valves) are closed.

Option B - C Wave of JVP: The C wave of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is associated with the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction, not with isovolumetric relaxation.

Option C - Corresponds to QT interval: The QT interval on an electrocardiogram represents the total time for ventricular depolarization and repolarization, not specifically isovolumetric relaxation.

questions.text: If radius of a vessel is doubled then the blood flow is increased by:
questions.solution:
Correct Options B - 16 times:

  • Flow is equal to pressure difference divided by resistance. So, flow is inversely proportional to the resistance of the vessel.
  • According to the Hagen–Poiseuille equation, resistance can be directly measured by the following formula.
    • R = 8ηL/pr4
    • Where,
      • R = resistance.
      • η = viscosity.
      • L = length.
      • r = radius of the vessel.
    • From this equation, the resistance of a vessel is inversely proportional to its r4 (radius).
    • If other parameters remain constant.
    • So, if the radius is doubled of the original, then the resistance will be:
    • R = 1/(2)4.
    • R = 1/16.
  • So, the resistance will decrease by 16 times.
  • So, the flow will increase by 16 times.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the cause of dicrotic notch?

choices.text: Passive filling of blood in ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Closure of semilunar valves:

  • Closure of semilunar valves: The dicrotic notch is a small downward deflection that occurs in the aortic pressure waveform after the closure of the aortic valve (semilunar valve).

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Dicrotic notch is formed due to closure of aortic valve.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Isovolumic relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Potassium ions:

  • Isovolumic relaxation is marked by closure of the semilunar valves and already closed atrioventricular valves. The duration of this phase is 0.06 sec.
  • It corresponds to the ‘v’ wave of jugular venous pulse.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Corresponds to QT interval: Ventricular depolarization and repolarization corresponds to the QT interval.

Options C and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Where do electrical impulses originate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option. A - SA node:

  • The SA node, also known as the pacemaker of the heart, is a specialized group of cells located in the right atrium. It is responsible for initiating the electrical impulses that regulate the heart's rhythm. The SA node generates electrical impulses spontaneously, causing the atria to contract and initiating the electrical conduction system of the heart.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B ,C, and D are incorrect. These structures are latent pacemakers of the heart and help in the conduction of electrical impulse.

questions.text: The cardiac event that occurs at the end of the isometric relaxation phase is?

choices.text: Corresponds to the peak of C wave in JVP
Corresponds to T wave in ECG

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Atrioventricular valves open:

  • The cardiac event that occurs after the isometric relaxation phase is the opening of the atrioventricular valves followed by the first rapid filling phase of the ventricles.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Atrioventricular valves close: Closure of atrioventricular valves marks the isovolumetric contraction phase.

Option C - Corresponds to the peak of the C wave in JVP: Isovolumic relaxation phase is marked by ‘v’ wave. The C wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction.

Option D -  Corresponds to the T wave in the ECG: The T wave in the ECG represents ventricular repolarization, which occurs before the isometric relaxation phase.

questions.text: PR interval in ECG denotes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Conduction through AV nodes:

  • The PR interval represents the time it takes for the electrical impulse to travel from the atria, through the atrioventricular (AV) node, and into the ventricles of the heart. It is measured from the beginning of the P wave (which represents atrial depolarization) to the beginning of the QRS complex (which represents ventricular depolarization).
  • The AV node acts as a gateway between the atria and the ventricles, slowing down the electrical impulse to allow for proper coordination and synchronization of atrial contraction before ventricular contraction. The PR interval, therefore, reflects the time it takes for the electrical signal to travel through the AV node.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ventricular depolarization: It is marked by the R wave of the ECG.

Option C - Ventricular repolarization: Ventricular repolarization is represented by the T wave on an electrocardiogram (ECG).

Option D - Atrial depolarization: It is represented by the P wave of the ECG.

questions.text: ‘c’ wave in JVP is seen in?

choices.text: Slow filling at end of diastole

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Iso-volumetric contraction:

  • The 'c' wave in the JVP is typically seen during the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle. It occurs during early ventricular systole when the tricuspid valve bulges back into the right atrium due to the increased pressure in the right ventricle. This causes a slight rise in the JVP.
  • The isovolumetric contraction occurs immediately after the closure of the atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) and before the onset of ventricular ejection.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Baroreceptor reflex is a type of __________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Negative feedback :

  • The baroreceptor reflex is a negative feedback mechanism that helps regulate blood pressure. It involves stretch receptors called baroreceptors, which are located in the walls of blood vessels such as the carotid sinus and aortic arch, as well as the heart. These receptors detect changes in blood pressure and send signals to the brain, specifically the cardiovascular control center in the medulla oblongata, to initiate a response.
  • When blood pressure increases, the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) is activated, which in turn activates the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) and inhibits the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM). This results in decreased sympathetic stimulation, leading to decreased cardiac output and contractility.
  • Conversely, if blood pressure decreases, the NTS and CVLM are not activated, which means they do not inhibit the RVLM. This leads to an increase in sympathetic supply, resulting in increased cardiac output.


 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the increase in resistance of an artery if its radius is reduced to one-third?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 81 times:

  • According to the Hagen–Poiseuille equation, resistance can be directly measured by the following formula.
  • R = 8ηL/pr4
  • Where,
    • R = resistance.
    • η = viscosity.
    • L = length.
    • r = radius of the vessel.
  • From this equation, the resistance of a vessel is inversely proportional to its r4 (radius). If other parameters remain constant.
  • So, if the radius is reduced by 1/3rd of the original, then resistance will be:
    • R = 1/ (1/3)4.
    • R = 81.
  • So, the resistance will increase by 81 times.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.
